column2: Trump calls Clinton corrupt and a liar	"

column1: By Emily Flitter
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Republican presidential hopeful Donald Trump staged a harsh attack on his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton on Wednesday
column2: accusing her of corruption and dangerous incompetence as he tried to put his campaign back on track after recent setbacks.In a speech in New York that Clinton's campaign called ""nutty"" and that was criticized by some Republicans
column3: Trump argued that the former secretary of state is part of a political establishment that has cheated American workers through bad trade deals and endangered U.S. national security.Both candidates are seeking to overcome their high unfavorable ratings among voters at the Nov. 8 election by painting the other as a villain who puts personal gain over the interests of less powerful Americans. Even by the standards of modern presidential races
column5: a former secretary of state and U.S. senator
column6: and brash businessman Trump has made for unusually acidic rhetoric.""Hillary Clinton may be the most corrupt person ever to seek the presidency of the United States
column7: Trump told a small crowd of supporters at a hotel he owns in Manhattan
column8: accusing her of having run the State Department ""like her own personal hedge fund."" Clinton's staff quickly dismissed that attack and others as ""lies.""Trump read his speech from a teleprompter to curb his off-the-cuff comments but he pulled no punches. He said Clinton ""has perfected the politics of personal profit and theft"" and described her as ""a world-class liar.""Republican Lindsey Graham
column9: a U.S. senator from South Carolina who has so far declined to support Trump
column10: said he disagreed that Clinton may be the most corrupt person to have run for the White House
column11: and challenged Trump to become more presidential.""My advice to Mr. Trump would be to make the case that you have the temperament
column12: knowledge and judgment to be president
column13: he said on CNN. ""That's the mountain you've got to climb.""Trump's campaign has been distracted in recent weeks by racially-charged comments he made about a Mexican-American judge and the Republican's firing of campaign manager Corey Lewandowski this week.

column1: The New York real estate mogul is trailing Clinton in most opinion polls
column2: and campaign finance figures released on Monday show he has raised only a fraction of the amount Clinton has brought in
column3: although Trump has said he is willing to loan his campaign more money.    CLINTON FOUNDATION

column1: In his speech
column2: Trump repeated accusations that Clinton's decisions as America's top diplomat were influenced by donations to the Clinton Foundation and associated charities. Clinton and her staff have denied this and similar allegations
column3: dismissing them as politically motivated smears.

column1: The only thing Donald Trump offered today was more hypocritical lies and nutty conspiracy theories
column2: Clinton spokesman Glen Caplin said.The State Department has said it is not aware of any evidence of improper influence
column3: although it has acknowledged that new donations from foreign governments should have been submitted to the department's ethics advisers for prior review but were not
column4: in breach of an ethics agreement Clinton signed before taking office.Trump attacked the Clinton Foundation for accepting millions of dollars from Saudi Arabia and other countries criticized by the United States for not protecting the rights of women and gay people. Clinton's husband
column6: has said that accepting such funding is not an endorsement of everything a foreign government does.Clinton added a pointed defense of the Clinton Foundation in a speech later on Wednesday.""The Clinton Foundation helps poor people around the world get access to lifesaving AIDS medicine
column7: she told cheering supporters in Raleigh
column8: North Carolina. ""Donald Trump uses poor people around the world to produce his line of suits and ties.""

column1: Trump also said Clinton had used bad political judgment in her four years as secretary of state
column2: failing to stop the rise of Islamic State
column3: keep strong sanctions on Iran or avoid chaos in Libya.""Her decisions spread death
column4: destruction and terrorism everywhere she touched
column6: Clinton delivered her own blistering attack on Trump
column7: saying that putting him in the White House would be a disaster for the U.S. economy. On Wednesday
column8: Clinton won the endorsement of former U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft
column9: a Republican who served under Presidents Gerald Ford and George H.W. Bush.A Reuters/Ipsos poll this week showed that 44.5 percent of likely voters backed Clinton
column10: while 35.5 percent supported Trump.Some of the accusations made by Trump on Wednesday appeared to contradict the public record.He said Clinton would admit hundreds of thousands of refugees to the United States without any prior screening. But under the current process
column11: refugees must wait months or years in foreign camps while U.S. security agencies review their backgrounds
column12: a system Clinton supports.Trump said Clinton was sleeping ""soundly"" in her bed as a deadly attack unfolded in Benghazi
column14: in 2012 in which four Americans were killed. State Department records show Clinton was in her State Department office when news of the opening assaults came through. She has said she later worked through the night on the U.S. response.             (Additional reporting by Jonathan Allen; Editing by Alistair Bell and Leslie Adler)"

4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-scotland-idUSKCN0Z8166	Trump to detour from campaign to visit Scotland golf properties	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Facing slumping poll numbers and a shakeup of his team
column2: U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump takes a detour from the campaign trail this week to visit his golf resorts in Scotland.Trump leaves Thursday on a three-day trip centered on the grand reopening of Trump Turnberry
column3: which the New York businessman bought in 2014 and renovated at an estimated cost of $290 million. He will also visit his other Scottish golf property in Aberdeen.His visit to Scotland
column5: comes as Britain votes on Thursday on whether to remain in the European Union. Trump has said Britain would probably be better off if it left the EU. He will hold a news conference on Friday when he will doubtless be asked to respond to the vote.Trump's trip abroad comes at an unusual time given the political calendar.With less than a month left until the Republican convention in Cleveland where he is to be formally nominated
column6: Trump is lagging in fundraising and campaign organization and taking heavy fire from Democrat Hillary Clinton
column7: his likely opponent in the Nov. 8 election.He is under pressure to adopt a more presidential demeanor and strengthen his campaign organization after a rocky period in which he criticized a U.S.-born federal judge as unfair because of his Mexican heritage and took fire for his response to the killing of 49 people at an Orlando
column10: he fired campaign manager Corey Lewandowski at the urging of family members alarmed at the direction of his campaign. It also emerged that he had only $1.3 million in cash on hand at the end of May to fund his campaign
column11: compared with  Clinton's war chest of $42 million.His poll numbers have also dropped. After sealing the nomination seven weeks ago
column12: Trump was basically tied in national polls with Clinton. But she has crept ahead in many polls in the past two weeks.

column1: 'PLACE WITH NO VOTERS'

Trump and his aides see the Scotland visit as a chance to showcase his far-flung business empire and job-creating abilities.Aides said the trip also reinforced his ancestral ties to Scotland and his love of family
column2: with his children playing an important role in his business dealings.

column1: But many Republicans see Trump's trip to Scotland as a waste of valuable time.""It has nothing to do with running for president
column2: said Republican strategist Rick Tyler
column3: who was a spokesman for  former presidential candidate
column4: U.S. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. ""It speaks to the non-seriousness of the campaign when you're taking time off the campaign trail to leave the country for a place where there are no voters.""Trump's golf properties are among his proudest business possessions and he is particularly proud of Turnberry
column5: where the British Open has been played four times
column6: including the famed ""Duel in the Sun"" in 1977 when Tom Watson edged Jack Nicklaus by one stroke.Limiting the trip to his golf properties means there are likely to be fewer chances for missteps like 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney's gaffe-filled trip to London
column7: Jerusalem and Poland four years ago.

column1: But it offers little chance for Trump to burnish his foreign policy credentials.""Traditionally
column2: nominees take overseas trips to build their foreign policy chops
column3: said Republican strategist Scott Reed.Trump is not meeting British Prime Minister David Cameron
column4: who has denounced Trump as divisive for his proposed Muslim ban and anti-immigrant rhetoric. (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-healthcare-ryan-idUSKCN0Z80AQ	House Republicans unveil healthcare alternative to Obamacare	"
By Eric Beech and Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives unveiled an alternative plan to overhaul the nation's healthcare system on Wednesday
column2: slamming Obamacare even as they aimed to keep some of its more popular provisions.Their proposal
column3: part of broader effort by House Speaker Paul Ryan to offer a Republican agenda ahead of the Nov. 8 elections
column4: is conservatives' latest bid to ""repeal and replace"" the 2010 law.Ryan
column6: is offering the proposal as the party seeks to maintain control of both the House and the Senate and take over the White House. Other proposals cover tax reform
column7: address poverty as well as national security.Republicans have challenged President Barack Obama's signature Affordable Care Act since it was enacted and have voted repeatedly to repeal it. Obama
column9: has said it has helped some 20 million Americans get health care coverage.Ryan acknowledged his agenda was unlikely to displace current law anytime soon.    ""We're not going to repeal Obamacare when the current president of the United States is a guy named Obama
column10: he told reporters. ""What we are laying out today is a first-time-in-six-years consensus by the Republicans in the House on what we replace Obamacare with.""

column1: In their plan
column2: which is not formal legislation
column3: House Republicans blasted Obamacare for limiting patients' choices
column5: and burying employers and health care providers under new regulations.Ryan's proposal would keep some popular pieces
column6: including not allowing people with pre-existing conditions to be denied coverage and permitting children to stay on their parents' coverage until age 26.It would also allow states that have already expanded the number of people eligible for Medicaid under the law to maintain the additional coverage
column7: although it would prevent any new states from doing so.

column1: For people without insurance through their jobs
column2: the Republicans would establish a refundable tax credit. Obamacare also provides subsidies for people to buy insurance if they do not qualify for Medicaid.It also includes long-held Republican proposals such as allowing consumers to buy health insurance across state lines
column3: expanding health savings accounts
column4: reforming medical liability rules and giving block grants to states to run Medicaid programs for the poor.Democrats
column5: who have said they are open to tweaking Obamacare
column6: dismissed Ryan's proposals as little more than warmed-over ideas that have long been in the Republican playbook.

column1: House Republican would gradually raise the Medicare eligibility age
column2: now 65
column3: to match that of the Social Security pension plan
column4: which is 67 for people born in 1960 or later.Like Obamacare's so-called Cadillac tax on expensive healthcare plans offered by employers
column6: the Republican proposal would cap the tax deductibility of employer-based plans. Industry groups struck a bipartisan tone in their reaction ahead of the election
column7: as it remains to be seen who ultimately wins control of Congress and the White House. ""We stand ready to work with both parties on market-based solutions that improve access and affordability for consumers
column9: president of America's Health Insurance Plans. (Reporting by Eric Beech
column10: Caroline Humer and Richard Cowan; Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Peter Cooney and Jeffrey Benkoe)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-insurance-idUSKCN0Z829W	Democratic senators ask Justice Department to block insurance megamergers	"
By Diane Bartz
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Seven Democratic senators urged the U.S. Justice Department on Wednesday to block two mergers of major health insurance companies
column2: saying that the proposed deals would mean higher premiums and lower-quality healthcare for consumers.The department is reviewing Aetna Inc's $33 billion plan to buy Humana Inc and Anthem Inc's $48 billion proposal to buy Cigna Corp. If approved
column3: the deals
column4: both of which were announced last July
column5: would reduce the number of national health insurance carriers from five to three.""We urge the DOJ (Justice Department) to challenge these mergers from proceeding and to prevent the damage they would cause to competition and consumers
column6: wrote Senators Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut
column8: Elizabeth Warren and Edward Markey of Massachusetts
column10: Dianne Feinstein of California and Mazie Hirono of Hawaii.The letter was dated Wednesday and addressed to Renata Hesse
column11: who heads the Justice Department's Antitrust Division.In the letter
column12: the lawmakers said they were skeptical of the idea that the proposed deals would be good for consumers because the companies could use their larger size to hammer out better deals for patients.

column1: The evidence overwhelmingly suggests that few if any cost savings secured by the merging firms through the exercise of market power will be passed on to consumers
column2: they wrote.The lawmakers also disagreed with the notion that the sale of carefully chosen assets to a competitor could resolve antitrust issues
column3: and pointed to past instances where mergers with divestitures led to higher premiums or where competitors bought divested assets
column4: but then did not use them.

column1: We are not convinced that any divestitures required of the merging parties will succeed today
column2: given that they have so clearly failed in the recent past
column3: the lawmakers wrote.Capitol Hill does not have a say in whether the Justice Department sues to stop deals.Aetna spokesman T.J. Crawford said that the company planned to close the merger with Humana in the second half of this year.

column1: We believe a combined company is in the best interest of consumers. We continue to cooperate with the Department of Justice on its thorough review of the transaction
column2: Crawford said.Representatives of Anthem could not immediately be reached for comment. (Reporting by Diane Bartz
column3: editing by G Crosse)"
